commentBody: That was fun. Definitely not a CEE, more like a SULPA

I hope all of the newest solvers 
enjoy this pleasant Monday diversion 
with an easy to see theme 
that adds to the solve 
but is not needed to fill in the letters.


Nice one, Alexander.

Swiss roll without cracking:

1. Use parchment paper in pan for easy removal from pan.

2. Make sure you cake is even before putting in oven.

3. Do not overcook. I slightly undercook. When inserting toothpick make sure that not completely clean.

4. Cover with slightly moist towel while cooling. Which prevents it from drying out and adds a slight bit of moisture.

5. Roll before becomes completely cool. Make sure filling is also at room temperature. Pipe on vs. Spreading so don't press into cake.

6. Use towel in step 4 to help roll.
oh dear only you yanks could call a main course an ENTREE :(

Puzzles like this, with words within phrases, never cease to amaze me. This one was the epitome, with the words spelled backwards. Wow. Congratulations and thank you, Mr. Liebeskind. Well done! SWISS ROLL reminded me of a time when I was known for mine, and was expected to turn up at every party with at least two. I made them the Brazilian way (known as "rocambole"), with a filling of creamy dulce de leche ("doce de leite" in Portuguese) and a sprinkling of fine crystal sugar all over the top. I had it all down to a science and could make them with my eyes closed, but it's been a few decades so I have no tips to give. That said, @Janis's comment has sparked some of my memory and I agree with all her tips, especially making sure the batter is even (i would bang the pan on the counter for that) and using that moist dish towel to help roll. Something else that took me way back was DELTA at 53D. Here is The Blessing with Delta Rain: https://youtu.be/HMNlQesC7Mk?si=kGMWq0nQF2n_QrF1 Hope you enjoy the song as much as I do and also as much as I enjoyed the puzzle, i.e., a lot!

My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Playground pathogen  (6)
2. Number at filling stations?  (9)
3. In the 80s or 90s, say  (4)(3)
4. Consumed with grief?  (6)(3)
5. Got online, say  (7)


COOTIE
NOVOCAINE
OVER PAR
STRESS ATE
ORDERED

Seeing 59D (OSLO) reminded me of a short “promotional” video presumably created by the city of Oslo encouraging potential visitors to stay away: - https://youtube.com/watch?v=8vhD59ac7nw Very funny, and I love the deadpan delivery of the guy featured in the video.
Did anyone else have the online puzzle mark 30A wrong even though it was right?

That was fast and fun and maybe just a bit FEISTIER than normal. 

I was moving through so furiously, I never contemplated the theme until I got to the end but then I fully appreciated it!

My only slow down was entering researchGRANT on my first round, before realizing it didn't work for the crosses and noticing the plural in the clue. The problem with trying for speed, which I only do on Mondays. 

I like that the theme included LOOK(ing) and the puzzle also included, AYES, EYE, I SPY, and CEE. 

But, there is still no I in TEAM!!

"That's not the correct way to write 99 in Roman numerals, though."
"IC."

(I'll have to sight my sources for this one.)

Really enjoyed this puzzle and took my time with it, liking the fill, the phrasing of the clues, the gentle humor. Look the other way is a great revealer (I thought it was going to be LOOKING BACKWARD). And there's lovely words/phrases in this one: FEISTIER, SHOE BILL, TREE POSE, SEMESTER AT SEA -- gives this puzzle a very rich and savory quality. Good stuff. In the daily Stuff in the Puzzle That's Not There Anymore (yesterday's was EEO), today we have FEDERAL GRANTS--> [Funding sources for many labs]: the article linked below shows that such grants have all but ceased or are in limbo: https://healthpolicy-watch.news/trump-administration-halts-health-communications-freezes-research-grants/ And, that old chestnut, a woman's right to choose (ROE).

My unforced error was believing that the comic strip Cathy was turned into a musical.  Ack. It has not. 

Who is gonna fix that issue?

Actually much longer than my best time and a tad longer than my average, but I had fun with this one - thanks to Alexander from Alexander! 
Is there really such a thing as a "semester at sea"?! Why wasn't I offered that?!
Well done and fun! To me a bit hard for a Monday.How come I've never heard of a sloe?
What am I missing -- why does 2.0 solve to "cee"
Reminder to vote for your favorite(s) for Puzzle of the Year 2024: Reminder: one vote per category! https://cdn.jotfor.ms/250186385916162

Will never understand why North Americans are the only place in the world who continue to refer to mains as entrées. While yes, I understand the history and how it came to be, dining has changed. 

Entrée is from the French entrer which literally means ‘to enter’. In this case, a dish serving as the entrance to a meal. 

We often now have appetisers as well but the rest of the world generally agrees upon apéritif > appetiser > entrée > main > dessert > digestif.
Can someone explain forced/unforced ERROR to me pls? Is this a sports thing?

userDisplayName: A Scared Doctor and Medical Researcher
commentBody:
It's so strange to see FEDERAL GRANTS clued as "funding sources for many labs" this week, as opposed to last week.  The National Institutes of Health (NIH) is the biggest funder of medical research in the world, and it is thanks to their support that many of the largest medical breakthroughs in the past several decades in cancer treatment, infectious disease, and other areas have happened.  NIH grant funding is crucial. 

Right now, ALL evaluation for ALL new NIH grants has stopped.  The sessions to discuss which grants should be funded have been canceled indefinitely and are not being re-scheduled.  Job offers at NIH itself have been rescinded.  Even if things get up and running again once a new Health and Human Services Secretary is named, some of this halting may take a long time to recover from, if at all.  And if Kennedy gets confirmed as the new HHS Secretary, it's not clear whether there will be ANY grant funding moving forward at all in crucial areas where medical advances have to be made.

The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) are also being hampered.  As of this week, they are not reporting the number of flu cases, for example, so nobody knows whether the national rates are going up or down. 

This is a very scary time for all of us.
My fist comment ever…. TREE POSE is not really a beginner yoga pose

I don't think this would fly in a Monday, but the constructor notes describe looking for an answer with E-C-N-A-L-G, so I came up with one:

[Bar staple at Burning Man, perhaps]
TRIPLE SEC NALGENE

Crossword Revolution Day 6: SHOEBILL The official bird of the crossword revolution: https://defendthemall.org/blog/2021/7/29/species-spotlight-shoebill * This is a Crosswords Saved the Day ™ production. (Given the presence of CONS over LOOK THE OTHER WAY, not to mention HARM, FIRES, FEDERAL GRANTS for scientific research (remember them?), I was briefly stymied, but if a bird can eat crocodiles, there is hope . . .)

A panicky moment when I got to the end of the crosses and had hardly anything filled in 😳. Lots of tricky clues on that first pass but it filled in pretty quickly on the downs.

A nice simple theme with a surprise when you bite into it. Fun idea and really nicely executed.
CEE for “2.0” is a bridge too far, especially on a Monday.

Such a fun Monday solve! Thank you, Alexander. Truly enjoyed the theme and fill. 

Happy Monday, everyone!!

Enjoyed it.

I almost panicled right off the bat when I thought I'd found an unresolvable NATICK, with 20A and 18D.  I don't know Spanish, and I certainly don't know emphatic Spanish, and I also know absolutely nothing about cotton.

I would have been a huge blow to my ego, as I'm become insufferably arrogant about my Monday solving abilities.
25 down: The clue is 'A pop' and the answer is 'each'. Would someone please enlighten me, as I am still in the dark regarding this one. Many thanks!

66 across "Main dish" being entree? Only in America.

This was an okay Monday imo.  I enjoyed seeing TESSA Thompson on the grid. I wonder if finding their names in a NYT crossword puzzle feels surreal to SASHA and Malia Ann Obama 🤔.

It seems as if 16A [Suitemate, e.g.] might have needed a qualifier like “informally” or some such because ROOMIE is a relaxed word for roommate. I wonder what others think about it.

FEDERALGRANTS may soon be a thing of the past and, yes, I’m in mourning about it.  So much research, creativity and entrepreneurial success emanated from these various federally funded programs. It would be an unthinkable loss. The whole situation is getting DIRE.

I worked myself into needing a TREEPOSE! Have a good week to everyone except… well, you know 😁.
Loved it!
Some reaches there...did not enjoy the cotton/spanish crossing. But SEMESTER AT SEA was delightful, particularly as a went-on-study-abroad-and-made-it-my-whole-personality person.
Although this sporting goods manufacturer primarily distributes hiking boots, I'm sure the loyal (and thirsty) customer could purchase a swag Hi-TEC NALGene water bottle: https://hi-tec.com/
Opened the column just hoping it would explain why 2.0 solved as Cee. Not disappointed!
Very satisfying AHA moment for me, so a fun Monday puzzle.

Fun Monday puzzle and a cute theme. A bit on the slow side for me, but just lots of nice 'aha' moments when something dawned on me from the crosses. And of course another nice moment when I finally tumbled to the theme. A kind of cute puzzle find today - a Wednesday from July 10, 2002 by Richard Silvestri. This one was all in the clues. Here are the theme clues and answers: "Twelve inches of supply boat? :" TENDERFOOT "Three feet of basketball floor? :" COURTYARD "Three miles of climbing vine? :" IVYLEAGUE "39.37 inches of stream? :" WATERMETER And here's the Xword Info link: https://xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/10/2002&g=33&d=A I'm done. ...

Did this one in the wee hours.  So looking back - see what I did there?* :) - a clever theme and a fun romp. 

TIL of the day is *nalgene*: I thought folks were just making that word up. 

*We have a friend who will invariably use that phrase anytime he says something clever.  The new "Get it?" I suppose.

This puzzle sure made me feEL GOod.  I think I’ll pick up a snack at the chucK WAGon.








Et tu, emu.
A little (14%) harder than average.  Good theme idea but I’m not looking back.  Happy Monday.

I wish I was there when Alexander saw the phrase LOOK THE OTHER WAY and this theme hit him.  What an OMG moment that had to be.  

It was a big enough moment for me – a jaw-dropping feeling – when I uncovered a few letters of that revealer and it hit me.  “Oh, perfecto!” I thought. I actually spontaneously fell into a moment of silent appreciation over the wit and beauty of it.

There are lovely backward-reading theme echoes in the grid as well.  Three palindromes (ALA, SMS, and EYE) and at least eight semordnilaps (STAR, MADE, GAS, ERA, RAG, ANTE, NOR, and TESSA).

Not to mention “look” synonyms in I SPY and EYE, the latter especially because even backwards it means to look.

I also liked the non-theme-related O-cluster in the NE, all in and about the word ROUNDS.  Ain’t that sweet?

At one point in my life I taught elementary school, and when the kids would get overly wild, I would stand them up and have them go into Tree Pose.  It never failed to calm the room down.

Not just a quick throw-away solve for me, Alexander, more like a rich bounty in the box today.  Thank you so much for making this!

A bit of eyebrow exercise at the notion of TREEPOSE being a “stance for a yoga beginner,” but otherwise enjoyable and smooth for my part,  I’m always impressed by people who can create crosswords.

Y’all have a lovely day and be kind to one another.  As St. Deb says, “Your mileage may vary.”

Nice theme, and a solid Monday puzzle.

Not familiar with PIMA, but AAH/PIMA seemed more likely than HAH/PIMH.

Especially as an exclamation, don't think "I see!" is really a Monday clue for AAH. But the same clue is used for 54D, I suppose because both resonate with the puzzle's theme.

Still, both AHA and HAH come to mind before AAH when I see "I see!".
In re: Swiss Rolls: I adore Stella Parks, who might have some tips for the rolling etc.! https://seriouseats.com/old-fashioned-jelly-roll

A slightly crunchy Monday for me; couldn’t understand 2.0 solving to CEE til I read Sam’s column. Thanks Sam. Obviously a specific US education thingy.
An enjoyable theme that still made me ponder a few answers. A nice way to spend yet another wet and wild day whilst named  storm No8 roars through. What is going on with the weather??

I had never heard of a SWISSROLL. I am assuming there are no fish involved.

Nice one Alexander, thank you

Holy cow!  This Monday gave me fits.  It wasn't just my reluctance to give up the HORNBILL perched in the center of the puzzle.  There was the SUMMER REU (Research Experience for Undergraduates) that I wanted to shoe-horn into that space one WAY or another.  And adding MALIA Obama to the mix, along with a JELLY ROLL.  
Tough old bird that I am, I got GRITTIER and tougher until forced to reconsider...  SHOEBILL, eh?  I'll tell you about SHOE BILLs!  Have you shopped for new SHOEs recently?  Wow.

Got the puzzle in the end, but not without pain (much of it self-inflicted, as I misread the numbers of the clues/spaces after my a.m. eyedrops.)  sheesh!

Didn't know TESSA or SOO, even though I recognize that at least the latter name has shown up before, and probably both of them.. I've never seen a Creed movie; the majority of  Stallone movies seem to be rehashes of either "Rocky" or "Rambo," so was never really interested, and Broadway is a long way from Atlanta. I've never played tennis, and I'll never stay at an OMNI, because neither are things I can afford to indulge in. A  RIDGE can be the crest of a mountain, but not necessarily, so it was enough of a stretch to elude me. ROOMIE seemed likely, but I had so few crosses that I was unsure of it, and I entered and deleted it several times.

So the northeast corner tore me up. I spent more time there than all the rest of the puzzle, and finally had to look up the actors' names before I could crack it. Considering this was a Monday puzzle, it was a little embarrassing

Easily  the trickiest Monday I remember in quite a while. I can usually work most of them out in my first pass, but this one took multiple rounds circling through to fill in all the open areas and correct my wrong guesses. Definitely not a complaint on my end, I like a challenge!

@Jill in Brooklyn 

I'm sorry to see that your post disappeared: it was clear to me from your follow-up responses that you had the opposite intention from how it had been interpreted. (I had written a response as much, but of course the whole thread went away, too.)

Tone is very difficult to read in plain text, and the lack of Edit functionality doesn't help, either. I try to read through any comment before hitting Submit, with varying results... 

I hope you're not dissuaded from posting again in the future! As a fellow Brooklynite said to me last night, "Community is everything." Here, too!

In the world of crossword constructors, I guess there isn't much difference between "clever" and intentionally obtuse or deceptive. Such was the case with 61D (2.0) today.

Double mis-direction here, insofar as "2.0" as an isolated clue could be a LOT of things, but then to add to the conundrum, the solution is to use the phonetic spelling of the answer as well.

P.S. to Sam...The AP classes I took in H.S. were awarded an extra point in our GPA (i.e., an A was 5.0 instead of 4.0, etc.). Virtually all of the top 10% of our graduating class had a GPA above 4.0. Some college admissions offices might have thought they were looking at typos on our transcripts.

FREEZINGPINT "Silver-tongued TV newsman?" BULLETINBARD "Comedian who has only one-liners?" CURTJESTER And some other theme answers: TWISTANDSHUT FUNDINGFATHERS THECASTISCLEAR QUIETASAMUSE Thought that was quite clever. As a doctor, I believe the clue for 19A is factually incorrect. Rounds are when your team make a series of visits to patients in the hospital and work out their treatment plans. The plan may include ‘professional calls’ for consults, but that’s AFTER rounds. Please feel free to correct me if I misinterpreted something.

@Tara 
Cake room temperature I find is the best. Frosting can be cool but i find room temperature is best and stay away from edge about 1/2 to 1 inch. And work quickly so cake does not dry out. Then chill. Do not pre-roll.... too much handling.

@Tara 
Cake room temperature I find is the best. Frosting can be cool but i find room temperature is best and stay away from edge about 1/2 to 1 inch. And work quickly so cake does not dry out. Then chill. Do not pre-roll.... too much handling. Towel is used to help roll. As it keeps it straight. Hard to explain without pictures.
@Tara I do roll it up in the towel before filling. It seems to make it easier to get it back to the rolled-up shape when you fill it.

Anyhow, it was really fun! We've done a lot of bar HP trivia but when I realized there was a HP Trivial Pursuit board game, I just had to get it and have a party at my place. Many more will follow, I predict. You have an open invitation!!  :-)
@Jones It’s a tennis term for when you hit a ball out that wasn’t caused by your opponent putting you in trouble with their shot.

@Mike 
Not just tennis. I occasionally pick a Wordle word with a yellow in the same place as in my last try - a blatant unforced error.

M-W calls an unforced error "a missed shot or lost point (as in tennis) that is entirely a result of the player's own blunder and not because of the opponent's skill or effort."

The term has since migrated from tennis to other sports.

@Barry Ancona It has also migrated to business and politics. Akin to chuting oneself in the foot. 

Spelling mistake intentional to fool the emus.
@Barry Ancona It has also migrated to general use especially in business and politics. Akin to shooting oneself in the foot.

@A Scared Doctor and Medical Researcher 

You are not alone.
parentUserDisplayName: A Scared Doctor and Medical Researcher

commentBody:
@A Scared Doctor and Medical Researcher 

Great, great post.

I am in mourning over what's happened to the US.

I can certainly see that science funding will be utterly absurd under the current administration.

It's just one more reason I believe the US is not only in decline, but in steep decline.

Why would talented science students from elsewhere come to a country which isn't funding relevant research?  Or why would faculty come to the US if they'll likely never get funding?
parentUserDisplayName: A Scared Doctor and Medical Researcher

commentBody:
@A Scared Doctor and Medical Researcher -- 

Normally, I like my puzzle to be a harbor from the ills of the world, and I do not like comments that rekindle those ills in my mind.

But these are indeed scary, highly unusual times, and seeing posts like yours, @Scared Doctor, remind me that I’m not alone, and bolster my vigilance to not LOOK THE OTHER WAY.  And I’m glad for them.

Thank you.
parentUserDisplayName: A Scared Doctor and Medical Researcher

commentBody:
@A Scared Doctor and Medical Researcher

commentBody:
@A Scared Doctor and Medical Researcher

USDA’s FoodKeeper app is no longer updating food recall information. I’m calling the DC office of the Chair of the House Ag Committee this morning to ask for immediate action on this and bird flu. It’s insane and people will get hurt.

Bird flu is proliferating and we are to know nothing of its progress.This is going to be a replay of his first-term failure to deal with COVID, one that cost thousands of lives.  What will it be this time, more Clorox injections and horse med?

commentBody: @Mindy you mean like it's not really a yoga pose?

@Scott

Yes, it’s a real pose and most classes include it.  It tests one’s balance and knee mobility but is easily modified.
@Trish okay so is the suggestion that it's not for beginners then?

@Mindy for the record I think tree pose has a reputation as a beginner pose because it is often used with kids. I get the sense that maybe the balance aspect makes out more difficult for adults just starting but elementary school teachers like it because it forces kids to concentrate and it's easy to explain.

@Mindy 

Welcome to the wacky world of crossword commenting!

@Mindy I came here just to see if anyone else would comment this. I’ve been doing yoga for 20+ years and agree tree pose is quite challenging when done as usually instructed (I.e., without modifications)

@Scott 
I was a teacher but never thought of using tree pose! Children have better balance generally and it would be easier for them.

@Mindy
I didn't know what TREEPOSE was -- I got it from the crosses.  Not a yoga person.  So looked it up.  There is no way I could do that!  

But I'm 75 years old with a bad left foot and a bad right knee.  Balance not so good.....
I can see my grandchildren doing it easily.
@Trish I was certain it was hornBILL. I wrestled with that one.

@Shimmer considering I don't understand the clue even after getting the answer from the crosses, you're probably not wrong. I will say though that I literally didn't notice it because it filled itself in. So it could have been worse

@Shimmer 

Yeah.  Not only is there the need to see it as a GPA, as opposed to a version number, there is the need to convert the letter "c" into cee.

@Shimmer 

The clue solved itself with crosses - and I'm glad it did! Otherwise it would be ungettable for me, beyond Saturday-level in difficulty.

@Shimmer, I'd agree, unless you were educated here in the US, which of course I cannot know. But through high school and college here, most schools use a four point scale: A=4, B=3, C=2, and D=1.

I'm not surprised by all the inquiries from various other countries!

@Francis 
Agree that this was the weakest fill of the puzzle. Those double As were the last letters I filled in.

@Francis 

My Spanish vocabulary is about 10 words (and half of that is the numbers 1 through 5), but after seeing SISI in puzzles every so often over the years, it's now a gimme, worth remembering, you'll see it again.

Dawn,

Your difficulty seems to have been in a different city in Massachusetts...

@Jay Werba 

I bought five cakes, 20$ each.

I bought five cakes, 20$ a pop.

"A pop" is a synonym of "each". 

It is also a quite common NYT crossword clue eo worth remembering 🙂
@Andrzej Got it......thank you for this!

@Jay Werba Thanks, I had the same question! 

And thanks to Andrzej  for the explanation.

@Francis Probably because "a pop" really means "a transaction". https://english.stackexchange.com/questions/77295/what-does-a-pop-mean The OED’s definition 3c of pop is ‘A turn at doing something; an attempt; a go; a time’ and the earliest citation supporting this sense is dated 1839.

@John Carson

Max Nicks,

@Matt 
Yes! I needed Sam’s explanation too.
@Helen Wright @Matt I'm so glad it was helpful!

@Rich in Atlanta Oh... and one more puzzle find. This one was just a bit unusual as there was no 'reveal' or hint to the theme, and all of what I 'think' are the theme answers were just clued quite straightforwardly. Here are what I believe are the theme answers: AMERICANME DELTADAWN SOUTHWESTAFRICA UNITEDWAY PANAMGAMES And here's the Xword Info link if you want to go take a look: https://xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/9/1997&g=23&d=A ...

@Jim 

Meant to add that I only scanned down a few previous entries before commenting so it is likely someone else made the same joke.

@Lewis 
After getting the first two themers, I was expecting the revealer to be "backwards glance."

@Barbara Prillaman 
I expect a beginner should attempt the tree pose, but it's not really FOR a beginner, if the full post is meant!

@Barbara Prillaman Well ok. TREE POSE
may not be the hardest one in the book(or out of it:) but there’s a lot you can do to embellish on it, i.e, with your arms behind your back looking up at the ceiling, or just arms straight with up in the air with eyes closed.
Saralyn, You might want to read this thread that started early yesterday evening: https://nytimes.com/shared/comment/44qgtp?rsrc=cshare&smid=url-share

@Saralyn and I will add Smitten Kitchen's Gingerbread Yule Log. Recipes on this site are very reliable, in my experience.

@Amy
I second the Smitten Kitchen gingerbread yule log - a yearly favorite for us! (And meet’s Deb’s easy to roll request.)

@Helen Wright 

The same storm front that gave Atlanta its first double snow days in the current century and at least one day when we had lower temperatures than McMurdo Station in Antarctica has crossed the Atlantic and is paying you a visit.

@Bruce 
Can I turn the lights out and pretend I’m not in?
@dkWatch The Great British Baking Show.It seems like they make Swiss Rolls every three days.

@Mean Old Lady 
I'd never heard of a SHOEBILL, because it's an African bird, and therefore not in my copy of Sibley's Guide. The roseate spoonbill was my first thought, but that was too long. Shoveler, then? (It's a duck.)

@Haim Wright Same here. Puzzle offered very little resistance today. 





Hello Emus.

Now, if I could only figure out the purple connection.

@Dakota 
All puzzles are released the evening before their official date. How early depends on your time zone and the day of the week (earlier on weekends). :)

New puzzles are released at 10pm et on weekdays, and 6pm et on weekends.
@Jane Wheelaghan Shaking My Head

@pat in oregon 
Oh-ho. So not Supermassive Black Hole? Makes much more sense now.

@Oikofuge 
I now have Muse’s ‘Super Massive Black Hole’ in my head. Nice.

@pat in oregon 
I thought you meant you were shaking your head at my ignorance, telling me the solution!

@Meg Fitch Thanks, Meg! I know that book is at my parents' house somewhere, so I'll look for the recipe. (I admit I've been making a vegan version, which may be why my hold on the art of the roll is so tenuous)

@Sam Corbin AAH, vegan! That does explain a lot: without the egg, it would be a lot more difficult to roll nicely. I did a search on "eggless swiss roll" and all the photos look a little sad. I know that a lot of Indian cooks are experienced at baking without using eggs, so I was excited to see a really nice-looking swiss roll from an Indian blogger. Turns out, she had issues too -- but came up with a workaround! Probably not what you're looking for, but interesting nonetheless... https://gayathriscookspot.com/2017/01/eggless-cake-roll-recipe/

@Grant 

That got an actual laugh from me -- out loud.

@Grant 

A new theme is born.  How many words can be found that contain IRE, RAGE, FURY, WRATH, etc. backwards?

@Amy 

I do so love being retired.

@Amy speaking of salt mines…you can visit one in Hutchinson Kansas.   Don’t get the second half of the tour…spoiler…there is more salt.

Also in Hutchinson is an air and space museum where you can see the actual Apollo 13.

@pat in oregon 

Read the circled letters backwards!

@pat in oregon 

When you don’t get a theme, look for a revealer. This is an answer, usually long and located in the center or lower half of the puzzle, that refers to a hint to other answers. 

This puzzle’s revealer is at 40A. It says [Ignore suspicious behavior, or a hint to the circled letters…]. The first part clues the literal answer to 40A, which is LOOK THE OTHER WAY. 

The second part of the clue helps you understand the theme. LOOK means you’re dealing with words that mean “to look”, and THE OTHER WAY means to enter them “the other way”. Since the normal way is left-to-right, those letters appear right-to-left. 

So in the first theme answer, the circled letters are EPAG, which when read backwards, is GAPE. The other three theme answers contain other synonyms for “look” written backwards in the circles. 

Hope this helps!

@Oikofuge 

Interesting how the two of us took quite different approaches to giving advice!

@Oikofuge 

I figure that on Monday, some people do need an instruction manual.

@HeathieJ 

Yes, Spanish and ESL, and thanks!

Your second sentence reminded me of that old light bulb joke:

How many psychiatrists does it take to change a light bulb?

Only one, but the light bulb has to want to change.

@Janine 

Hope I will be prepared! I encountered it in a 2023 archived puzzle very recently. Recently enough that I knew I knew but couldn't access it. Fortunately, the crosses did their trick!  :-)

@Janine 
Be careful, PIMA and Giza are both high-end varieties of cotton, prized for both softness and durability. I could see that as a Kea/Loa conundrum.

@Grant 

PIMA has appeared 80 times, usually clued as the cotton (otherwise as the southwestern tribe); GIZA has appeared 26 times, always clued as the locale in Egypt. 

Also, I’d venture that PIMA cotton is much  better known than GIZA cotton. 

Guess accordingly.

@Steve L 
I'm guessing that your news outlet of choice does not feature My Pillow Guy advertisements. Giza cotton is definitely a selling point.

@John 
Me too. I went to the column looking for a clue and didn’t find it. So I began doing the downs first ands it finally clicked.
@Byron - I found today's rather easy. What "rule" is it you think was broken? https://nytimes.com/2025/01/26/crosswords/connections-companion-596.html
@Byron It's not the first that's pulled that stunt.  It won't be the last.

@Byron 
I got them all, no mistakes, but I understand what you're referring to, and the only way it seemed possible was after the blue and purple were the only connections left, and the questionable connection had to be right. Some people saw it as a puzzle within a puzzle and therefore okay, but I don't agree.

@Byron I don't feel any "rules" were broken. What was odd was the given "explanation" of the connection for one of the four groups. (Trying to avoid spoilers here.)

But, to me, there were four connected groups. I could easily replace the given odd explanation with another one that would certainly connect the words in that group.
@Byron I can validate that it was different today.
@Byron I’m pretty sure the first rule of connections is that you don’t talk about connections.

@G 
I wasn’t at all surprised at the disappearance of the thread, but the OP started off pretty well complimenting the liveliness of the commentary found here. They said they were a first-time commenter and someone suggested starting over with a new handle. Nah, just come back as Jill from Brooklyn and try a slightly different approach. I think you will fit in just fine. BTW, I tried to post a response but it got lost in the resultant melee. The subject of Spiro Agnew came up and I just had to revise the W.Safire quip SA made famous in 1970. “In the word play commentary site we have more than our share of the nattering nabobs of negativism. They have formed their own 4-H club — the hopeless, hysterical hypochondriacs of history”. All meant in good fun🤗

@G 

Could we have a revised version of the post so we'll know what you're referring to? Jill will have the original post in her email box if she was was notified when the initial post was  accepted.

@Hardroch 

I was really excited by Joan's original post.  I loved that she appreciated the community and its liveliness.  Something about the overall tone makes me almost certain that the offending words were meant as a joke.  I, too, often run off by mouthing the absurd things.

@dutchiris 

I didn't see the entire string of replies, but I replied twice to her original post, the first making a joke of the "offensive" part of her post, and a second saying I was betting on it being sarcasm.

But there were some other posts that I would have agreed with had it NOT been sarcasm.  And I would imagine those could get pretty ugly.

So I really hope Joan comes back, but given that her *very first post* created a firestorm, I very much doubt it.

Joan, if you're reading this, don't give up on us quite yet.

@Francis 

Wished I saw the comments before they were removed.  I'm so intrigued! 

Signed,
Nosy Nellie

@HeathieJ 

I wish we could go back to them, too.  I obviously didn't see all the replies, because I didn't see anything about Spiro T. Agnew (still got to be the funniest name of any Vice President).

@Francis 

Oh no, now you've got me wondering if I have the wrong name! Ack, was it Jill or Joan?? 

What I do know is the rest of what we've been referring to is true to the content of that thread. 

Oh geez, if I got her name wrong, I'm so sorry!

@G

I read her comment earlier today and didn’t realize it was sarcasm. It was more like whoa, that’s pretty brutal.  Her subsequent comment cleared it up but I gotta say, I am surprised she thought it would be seen as humor.

@Cyndie 

She's a new commenter, and given that she says shes from Brooklyn, she might not know how touchy liberals in battle zones are.

@Francis Well, I don’t know if liberals are any touchier than the average bear and I’m not especially liberal but I took it took it as a serious comment. Admittedly, things can come across very different than intended without tone or facial expressions.

@MarkInTheMountains

Nowadays grade inflation has created many GPAs over 4.5 at my local high school! I think universities have a way to account for it, though.

@MarkInTheMountains 
FWIW, this exact clue/answer pair has appeared before about ten times in its singular or plural form. [#2] has also appeared numerous times, cluing a variety of answers.Just this month to pencils. Seems like fair wordplay to me.
@MarkInTheMountains I hope that everyone breezed right into their top-choice schools with those 5.0s!

@Sam Corbin This was 1969, so I'm not sure how widespread the "tracking" practice was back then. They didn't refer to it as AP classes that I can remember. We may have had a few kids get into "upper crust" colleges, but it was a small H.S. in the midwest (285 in our class) just east of St. Louis. I know a couple kids that got into Notre Dame, St. Louis U and a sprinkling of respected Jesuit run colleges, but no Ivy's that I remember.

@MarkInTheMountains 

I was in high school in 1969.  Nobody ever offered me an AP class. 

But that's the thing about the American education system.  It's supported primarily from local tax bases, and the wealthy schools have enormous abundance because they're in a wealthy district, and poor schools have almost literally nothing because they're in a poor district.

Of course, what happens is that very few people in either group get a good education--the wealthy don't because they don't think they need it because they're already rich.  And the poor because they are not really even being offered an education.

@ExpatByChoice 

It's an American idiom.  "a pop" means the same as each.

I have no idea what the origin is, but it's something that a non-English speaker would have no clue about.

Like Andrzej wrote below these two sentences means exactly the same thing:

I bought doughnuts for $1.50 each.
I bought doughnuts for $1.50 a pop.

@ExpatByChoice 

It's just an expression, "a pop."

It means each one. Ten dollars a pop.

You can find "a pop" in the entry for "pop" in Merriam Webster.

@Francis 
The Oxford English Dictionary connects the sound "pop" first to "a pop" meaning "a moment" (ie the duration of a pop), and thence to "a pop" meaning a [presumably brief] attempt, and thence to the current usage. Interestingly, their first citation for that last is from Mark Twain, who said he was charging "$100 a pop" for lectures (in 1868).
@Francis Thank you!

@Francis 

I left you a comment about an hour or so ago, agreeing with you and saying that the interesting comment section today wasn't good for my already struggling to be productive at work situation... And I also mentioned the Penske file. I don't know why the emus didn't let it through

@Kisha

The retina of the human eye has ‘rod’ cells and ‘cone’ cells which are light sensitive.
@Kisha https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/body/photoreceptors-rods-and-cones
